cards.meaning: Brief and to the point; Effectively cut short.
cards.example: Jessica is so talkative that her sister thought the situation warrated conciseness and her being laconic.

cards.meaning: Lacking taste or flavor
cards.example: Too much sugar makes this otherwise delightful fruit pie insipid.

cards.meaning: Concerned with practical matters
cards.example: After five years of war, both sides have found pragmatic ways to make peace with one another, as the bloodshed has grown viscous and brutal.

cards.meaning: someone who attacks cherished beliefs or institutions
cards.example: He is often seen as a rebel, an iconoclast who follows his own rules.

cards.meaning: involving or requiring strenuous effort; difficult and tiring.
cards.example: In those days, a trip to the West was an arduous journey.

cards.meaning: recklessly extravagant or wasteful in use of resources
cards.example: Spending £13,000 on a handbag seems offensively profligate.

cards.meaning: without interest, imagination, and excitement; dull;
cards.example: He asked if I'd got my black eye in a fight - I told him the prosaic truth that I'd banged my head on a door.

cards.meaning: to make a bad or unpleasant situation better
cards.example: Foreign aid is badly needed to ameliorate the effects of the drought.

cards.meaning: too eager to praise or obey someone; excessively obedient
cards.example: She is embarrassingly obsequious to anyone in authority.

cards.meaning: likely to change, or reacting to a sudden desire or new idea
cards.example: The decision rejected the notion of an arbitrary and capricious power accruing to state securities commissioners.

cards.meaning: happening by chance rather than intention; fortunate
cards.example: The collapse of its rivals was a fortuitous opportunity for the company.

cards.meaning: conforming to all the traditional beliefs, and religious practices; acceptable
cards.example: Orthodox strategies for socio-economic development in developing countries.

cards.meaning: lively and cheerful readiness; eagerness
cards.example: I am sure that they will be accepted with alacrity, knowing my noble friend's expertise in such matters.

cards.meaning: very clear and shining; very clear in meaning and easy to understand
cards.example: the pellucid light of a spring morning.

cards.meaning: confirm or give support to; add information to an idea
cards.example: Recent research seems to corroborate the theory.

cards.meaning: very kind and generous towards someone you have defeated; forgiving
cards.example: The team's manager was magnanimous in victory, and praised the losing team.

cards.meaning: diligent; thorough; honest; extremely careful
cards.example: The nurse told him to be scrupulous about keeping the wound clean.

cards.meaning: producing a great number or amount of something; fruitful
cards.example: Harada has been prolific, releasing more than 70 singles.

cards.meaning: opinionated; strongly expressing your beliefs as if they were facts;
cards.example: If you are dogmatic, you are certain that you are right and that everyone else is wrong.

cards.meaning: to stop someone from feeling angry or hostile.
cards.example: Outraged minority groups will not be placated by promises of future improvements.

cards.meaning: changing suddenly and often; temperamental
cards.example: She was entertaining but unpredictable, with mercurial mood swings.

cards.meaning: make something already bad, worse; infuriate;
cards.example: This attack will exacerbate the already tense relations between the two communities.

cards.meaning: unnecessary because it is more than is needed; superfluous
cards.example: In the sentence "She is a single unmarried woman", the word "unmarried" is redundant.

cards.meaning: Unoriginal; Trite; Tedious and uninspiring
cards.example: The plot of the film is just a hackneyed boy-meets-girl scenario.

cards.meaning: careful and avoiding risks; showing care and thought
cards.example: It's always prudent to read a contract carefully before signing it.

cards.meaning: to show something to be false, or to hide something such as an emotion.
cards.example: Her calm face belied the terror she was feeling.

cards.meaning: intended for or understood by only a few people who have special knowledge; obscure
cards.example: Literary readings can sometimes seem esoteric, but we are trying to make them more attractive to more people.

cards.meaning: an unpleasant mixture of loud sounds
cards.example: The cacophony surrounding the multi-billion dollar buyout of leading messaging service by a social networking company shook the whole tech industry.

cards.meaning: likely to do something suddenly, without considering the results of your actions
cards.example: He's so impetuous - why can't he think things over before he rushes into them?

cards.meaning: a strange or unusual habit, way of behaving, or feature
cards.example: One of the idiosyncrasies of this printer is that you can't stop it once it has started.

cards.meaning: used to refer to something very old that is still existing
cards.example: Phyllis Wheatley is the author of the earliest extant volume of poetry by an African American.

cards.meaning: not clear and difficult to understand or see; not known to many people
cards.example: Official policy has changed, for reasons that remain obscure.

cards.meaning: intended to teach, especially in a way that is too determined or eager, and often fixed and unwilling to change
cards.example: Children’s books possess a practical, didactic purpose – to instill a love for reading.

cards.meaning: brief; to the point;  expressing an idea cleverly in a few words.
cards.example: He was considered a superb and pithy writer.

cards.meaning: in large amounts, or more than enough
cards.example: He took copious notes during the lecture.

cards.meaning: a vulgar show of wealth, possessions, or power intended to attract admiration or notice; show-off
cards.example: Her luxurious lifestyle and personal ostentation were both hated and envied.

cards.meaning: alter or debase often for profit; to make something weaker or of worse quality by adding something else to it
cards.example: Saffron is very expensive, and is often adulterated with other plants.

cards.meaning: loud and clamorous
cards.example: Local activist groups have become increasingly vociferous as the volume of traffic passing through the village has increased.

cards.meaning: tending not to speak much; reserved; uncommunicative in speech
cards.example: He was always quiet, reserved, and taciturn.

cards.meaning: extremely determined to act in a particular way and not to change despite what anyone else says; stubborn
cards.example: Union leaders remain obdurate that working conditions and pay improve.

cards.meaning: excessively talkative; having the habit of talking a lot, especially about things that are not important
cards.example: I had talked too much about myself and felt like a garrulous old fool.

cards.meaning: someone who dislikes or hates and avoids other people
cards.example: He is a hard-cursing, chain-smoking misanthrope who formerly worked on a children's television programme.

cards.meaning: to make someone famous, or to treat someone as if they were famous
cards.example: During her reign he was much lionized as a military hero of incredible valor.

cards.meaning: about to happen
cards.example: He gave a dire warning that an earthquake was imminent.

cards.meaning: to laugh at someone or something in a way that shows you think they are stupid or of no value; insult
cards.example: This building, once derided by critics, is now a major tourist attraction.

cards.meaning: lazy; sluggish;  feeling unwilling and unable to do anything
cards.example: He was found to be pale, thin, wasted and lethargic, with slow and confused answers, according to the hospital's discharge summary.

cards.meaning: only recently or partly formed, or not completely developed or clear; undeveloped;
cards.example: He is easily intimidated when the left condemns this vague, inchoate mixture of family loyalty and patriotism as the bigotry of the extreme right.

cards.meaning: felt or experienced very strongly or in an extreme way; thoughtful
cards.example: The invention of the contraceptive pill brought about profound changes in the lives of women.

cards.meaning: a person who is too interested in formal rules and small details that are not important
cards.example: Harrison is a pedant who would rather waste his time bickering than letting trivial things go.

cards.meaning: extreme happiness, sometimes more than is reasonable in a particular situation
cards.example: The cricket team players where euphoric after their world cup victory.

cards.meaning: something that is mysterious and seems impossible or difficult to understand completely
cards.example: The newspapers were full of stories about the enigma of the plane's disappearance.

cards.meaning: having two opposing feelings at the same time, or being uncertain about how you feel; conflicting
cards.example: I felt very ambivalent about leaving home.

cards.meaning: to be uncertain what to do, or to change often between two opinions; be indecisive
cards.example: Her mood vacillated between hope and despair.

cards.meaning: ​weak and cowardly (= not brave); frightened of taking risks; fearful;
cards.example: He's too pusillanimous to stand up to his opponents.

cards.meaning: ​lasting for only a short time; momentary; passing
cards.example: Fame in the world of rock and pop is largely ephemeral.

cards.meaning: ​(of a person) unwilling to obey orders or to do what should be done, or (of an animal) refusing to be controlled
cards.example: Tenants petitioned their recalcitrant landlord to finish repairs to their building.

cards.meaning: ​giving too much attention to small details and wanting everything to be correct and perfect;​
cards.example: He is very fastidious about how a suitcase should be packed.

cards.meaning: ​ more than is needed or wanted; unnecessary
cards.example: The report was marred by a mass of superfluous detail.

cards.meaning: ​harmful; limiting
cards.example: Excessive managerial control is inimical to creative expression.

cards.meaning: ​to speak in a way that is intentionally not clear and confusing to other people, especially to hide the truth
cards.example: She accused the minister of equivocating, claiming that he had deliberately avoided telling the public how bad the problem really was.

cards.meaning: ​someone who tends to talk a lot; talkative
cards.example: I was talking, as one always does, to a loquacious taxi driver.

cards.meaning: ​​to make people have a particular feeling or make a situation start to exist; cause or give rise to
cards.example: The vice-president's speech did not engender confidence in his judgment.

cards.meaning: ​​​causing sleep or making a person want to sleep; causing drowsiness
cards.example: Soon thereafter, however, he found the world of academia restrictive and soporific.

cards.meaning: ​​​​suggesting a positive and successful future
cards.example: Winning her first seven cases was an auspicious beginning for the young lawyer.

cards.meaning: tending to spend or use something without thinking of the future; wastefully extravagant
cards.example: There have been rumours that he has been prodigal with company funds.

cards.meaning: ​to make someone feel weak and without energy; wear out
cards.example: Even educational establishments are suspect on the ground—not unnatural after his own experience of Oxford—that their possibilities of comfort may enervate the natural energies of men.

cards.meaning: passionate; intensely enthusiastic
cards.example: They hurled fervid accusations at each other during the debate.

cards.meaning: secretive; unwilling to speak about your thoughts or feelings
cards.example: He is very reticent about his past.

cards.meaning: confused; disorderly;
cards.example: The crowd at the concert was tumultuous, and went berserk.

cards.meaning: showing a willingness to take risks or offend people; reckless; daring
cards.example: The car maker's audacious goal is to compete with the luxury cars of other manufacturers.

cards.meaning: completely harmless (= causing no harm); inoffensive
cards.example: Some mushrooms look innocuous but are in fact poisonous.

cards.meaning: to publicly support or suggest an idea, development, or way of doing something
cards.example: She advocates taking a more long-term view.

cards.meaning: having little value or importance;
cards.example: I don't know why he gets so upset about something so trivial.

cards.meaning: a person, thing, or idea that exists out of its time in history, especially one that happened or existed later than the period being shown, discussed, etc.
cards.example: For some people, marriage is an anachronism from the days when women needed to be protected

cards.meaning: to support or improve something or make it stronger; strengthen
cards.example: More money is needed to bolster the industry.

cards.meaning: having or containing a lot of knowledge that is known by very few people; well educated; cultured
cards.example: He's the author of an erudite book on Scottish history.

cards.meaning: very careful and with great attention to every detail
cards.example: Many hours of meticulous preparation have gone into writing the book.

cards.meaning: very intelligent and skilful, or skilfully made or planned and involving new ideas and methods; original; inventive
cards.example: Johnny is so ingenious - he can make the most remarkable sculptures from the most ordinary materials.

cards.meaning: said in a clear and short way; expressing what needs to be said without unnecessary words
cards.example: Keep your letter succinct and to the point.

cards.meaning: expressed too often to be interesting or seem sincere; silly; commonplace
cards.example: I know it will sound trite, but I've loved being part of this club.

cards.meaning: to honour or very much respect a person or thing
cards.example: Many families had a special saint they used to venerate.

cards.meaning: positive and hoping for good things; optimistic; red
cards.example: They are less sanguine about the prospects for peace.

cards.meaning: seeming likely to be true, or able to be believed
cards.example: a plausible explanation/excuse

cards.meaning: ​different in every way
cards.example: The two cultures were so utterly disparate that she found it hard to adapt from one to the other.

cards.meaning: ​causing or intending to cause harm or evil; evil itself
cards.example: Foreign domination had a malign influence on local politics.

cards.meaning: tending to argue, fight, or complain, and hard to control; quarrelsome; irritable
cards.example: The fractious nature of politics

cards.meaning: the quality of being shy and not confident of your abilities; hesistance
cards.example: He spoke with a certain diffidence which added to his charm

cards.meaning: happening exactly when needed but without being planned;
cards.example: Therefore, it is providential that this vast and powerful new form of energy has arrived just at this moment.

cards.meaning: able to think clearly or make good decisions because of not being influenced by emotions; unfeeling
cards.example: In all the media hysteria, there was one journalist whose comments were clear-sighted and dispassionate.

cards.meaning: hostile; aggressive;
cards.example: The belligerent countries are having difficulties funding the war.

cards.meaning: a speech, piece of writing, poem, etc. containing great praise, especially for someone who recently died or retired from work
cards.example: The song was a eulogy to the joys of travelling.

cards.meaning: to refuse to accept something as the truth; deny; contradict
cards.example: Certainly there's no gainsaying (= it is not possible to doubt) the technical brilliance of his performance.

cards.meaning: clever, dishonest talk or behaviour that is used to deceive people; deception; trickery
cards.example: The investigation revealed political chicanery and corruption at the highest levels.

cards.meaning: to avoid telling the truth or saying exactly what you think; deceive; stretch the truth
cards.example: Aron does not take bad news well and hence her brother always prevaricates when telling her something she does not want to hear.

cards.meaning: happening sometimes; not regular or continuous; scattered or isolated
cards.example: The gunfire was sporadic.

cards.meaning: quiet and easy to influence, persuade, or control; submissive; compliant
cards.example: The once docile population has finally risen up against the ruthless regime.

cards.meaning: accuse or blame
cards.example: he blamed himself, but also inculpated his fiancée

cards.meaning: disagreement;  a combination of sounds or musical notes that are not pleasant when heard together
cards.example: Historical interpretations exist in groups, and sometimes support each other for reasons of social function despite apparent methodological dissonances.

cards.meaning: pleasant and kind; gentle
cards.example: His humour was benign, never cruel or hurtful.

cards.meaning: behaving in a silly way and not taking anything seriously
cards.example: With our justice system there are a lot of frivolous cases that go to court.

cards.meaning: very noticeable or attracting attention, often in a way that is not wanted; obvious
cards.example: He tried not to look conspicuous and moved slowly along the back of the room.

cards.meaning: old-fashioned or outdated.
cards.example: Compared with modern satellite dishes, ordinary TV aerials look positively antiquated.

cards.meaning: a large amount or supply of something; abundant supply
cards.example: Compared with modern satellite dishes, ordinary TV aerials look positively antiquated.

cards.meaning: of great importance
cards.example: He did, however, start off with the right credentials to become a major playwright: he considered disrespect for authority a cardinal virtue.

cards.meaning: violent hate and anger expressed through severe criticism; abusive language
cards.example: His tendency toward insult and vitriol offended most critics, who called him outrageous, belligerent, and self-righteous.

cards.meaning: the state of being the most important thing
cards.example: The government insists on the primacy of citizens' rights.

cards.meaning: to receive and accept information, etc.; absorb ideas; to drink
cards.example: They were men who had imbibed the psychology of colonial subordination.

cards.meaning: most essential part; essence; the spongy white tissue lining the rind of oranges, lemons, and other citrus fruits.
cards.example: the pith and core of socialism.

cards.meaning: used to describe something as another, more exciting, interesting, or unusual thing, as a way of emphasizing its character; without a doubt
cards.example: My garden had become a veritable jungle by the time I came back from holiday.

cards.meaning: simple and severe with no comfort
cards.example: They lead a spartan life, with very few comforts and no luxuries.

cards.meaning: staying the same for a long time and not changing quickly or unexpectedly; unwaivering
cards.example: The group remained steadfast in its support for the new system, even when it was criticized in the newspapers.

cards.meaning: dishonest talk or behaviour, especially by saying different things to two people
cards.example: They were accused of duplicity in their dealings with both sides.

cards.meaning: in such a strong position that you cannot be defeated; immune to attack
cards.example: The president looked unassailable with over 60 percent of the vote.

cards.meaning: boring, ordinary; cliché
cards.example: He just sat there making banal remarks all evening.

cards.meaning: lack of interest, or the attitude of not caring resulting from it
cards.example: There is a growing sense of apathy among teens and a feeling that there are no opportunities, he said.

cards.meaning: (especially of men) attractive, confident, and carefully dressed
cards.example: He is duped by a debonair con man into opening a car and safe, and lands in jail for a year.

cards.meaning: making a certain situation or outcome likely or possible.
cards.example: the harsh lights and cameras were hardly conducive to a relaxed atmosphere

cards.meaning: the method and practice of teaching, especially as an academic subject or theoretical concept.
cards.example: Professors aim to get tenure at the expense of pedagogy.

cards.meaning: abnormal narrowing of a bodily canal or passageway; severe criticism
cards.example: "the strictures imposed by the British Board of Film Censors.

cards.meaning: the appearance of being true or real.
cards.example: The detail gives the novel some verisimilitude.

cards.meaning: to try to destroy or damage something
cards.example: The rebel army is attempting to subvert the government.

cards.meaning: (of a law or decision) in a way that affects a date before it was approved
cards.example: The courts cannot apply a new rule retroactively

cards.meaning: Irregularly; happens suddenly in short bursts.
cards.example: He made spasmodic attempts to clean up the house.

cards.meaning: never stopping, especially annoyingly or unpleasantly:
cards.example: It was raining incessantly

cards.meaning: false and not what it appears to be, or (of reasons and judgments) based on something that has not been correctly understood and therefore false
cards.example: Some of the arguments in favour of shutting the factory are questionable and others downright spurious.

cards.meaning: refusing to change your opinions or behaviour
cards.example: Unions claim that the management continues to maintain an intransigent position

cards.meaning: calm and not showing emotion or excitement; not interesting or attractive
cards.example: He's a very stolid, serious man

cards.meaning: (especially of men) attractive, confident, and carefully dressed
cards.example: Abhinav is a debonair young man ;)

cards.meaning: preventing new ideas from developing; limited in growth
cards.example: These countries are trying to shake off the stultifying effects of several decades of state control.

cards.meaning: To avoid something intentionally, or to give something up
cards.example: We won't have discussions with this group unless they eschew violence.

cards.meaning: To exist in an unpleasant or unwanted situation, often for a long time.
cards.example: The ruling party is languishing in third place in the opinion polls.

cards.meaning: Very educated people in a society, especially those interested in the arts and in politics
cards.example: He went on to join the intelligentsia.

cards.meaning: obvious, without any attempt to be hidden
cards.example: He told me a brazen lie.

cards.meaning: the fact that the different parts of something exist in or have been arranged into separate groups
cards.example: The prime minister wants to reduce social stratification and make the country a classless societ

cards.meaning: Extremely cowardly; not brave
cards.example: The heckler acted cravenly after being identified.

cards.meaning: (especially of a company) not having enough money to pay debts, buy goods, etc.
cards.example: The firm was about to become insolvent, by the time the new CEO stepped in.

cards.meaning: A group or person having low moral standards
cards.example: It was a decadent monarchy.

cards.meaning: separated from and communicating little with the outside world
cards.example: These academics led a cloistered life.

cards.meaning: very simple and without comfort or unnecessary things, especially because of severe limits on money or goods; unfriendly
cards.example: He had an austere childhood during war.

cards.meaning: (a way of) being saved from danger, loss, or harm
cards.example: Scoring 330+ was his salvation

cards.meaning: avoiding physical pleasures and living a simple life, often for religious reasons
cards.example: Monks live an ascetic life.

cards.meaning: without knowledge or morals
cards.example: Some of the early explorers thought of the local people as benighted savages who could be exploited.

cards.meaning: to describe or think of someone as if they are extremely good and have no faults; the pope declares someone's life as holy
cards.example: He beatifies his first wife while celebrating his own extra-marital affairs.

cards.meaning: Very generous
cards.example: The new PM was anything but munificent.

cards.meaning: saying exactly what must happen, especially by giving an instruction or making a rule.
cards.example: Most teachers think the government's guidelines on homework are too prescriptive.

cards.meaning: not known or understood by many people.
cards.example: An abstruse philosophical essay.

cards.meaning: extravagantly theatrical; relating to opera
cards.example: she wrung her hands in operatic despair

cards.meaning: to change an order that has already been given, especially by giving a new order
cards.example: As your superior, I countermanded that will!

cards.meaning: (of a person or behavior) praising people in authority in a way that is not sincere, usually, to get some advantage from them.
cards.example: There was sycophantic laughter from the audience at every one of his terrible jokes.

cards.meaning: a person who understands and enjoys beauty; appreciates art
cards.example: The ugliness of the city would make an aesthete like you shudder.

cards.meaning: a person making an inquiry, especially one seen to be excessively harsh or searching.
cards.example: The professional inquisitors of the press

cards.meaning: a person who refuses to see the beauty or the value of art or culture:
cards.example: I wouldn't have expected them to enjoy a film of that quality anyway - they're just a bunch of philistines!

cards.meaning: to walk taking slow steps, as if your feet are heavy; boring, sleep inducing
cards.example: For years, he's plodded away at the same dull routine job.

cards.meaning: to praise something or someone very much
cards.example: She is forever extolling the virtues of her children.

cards.meaning: nonsense or boring and unnecessary information:
cards.example: You don't believe the drivel you read on the internet, do you?

cards.meaning: giving too much attention to small details that are not important in a way that annoys other people.
cards.example: Meticulous to a fault, Sarah is often considered persnickety.

cards.meaning: doing only what you want and often changing your behaviour in a way that is difficult to control
cards.example: If you keep acting like that, they will think of you as wayward.

cards.meaning: (especially of children) showing mental development or achievement much earlier than usual.
cards.example: She recorded her first CD at the precocious age of twelve.

cards.meaning: unreasonably determined, especially to act in a particular way and not to change at all, despite what anyone else says
cards.example: her obstinate refusal to compromise

cards.meaning: perfect, or complete in every way
cards.example: He's a consummate athlete/gentleman/liar.

cards.meaning: To defeat a competitor by a large margin
cards.example: France trounced Germany by five goals to one in the qualifying match.

cards.meaning: to severely criticize someone, especially in a public way
cards.example: Although regularly pilloried by the press as an obnoxious loudmouth, he is, nonetheless, an effective politician.

cards.meaning: a piece of writing, a drawing, etc. that criticizes a famous person or a public organization in a humorous way, allowing their or its bad qualities to be seen and making them or it seem stupid
cards.example: The magazine is famed for its merciless political lampoons.

cards.meaning: a willingness to do or say something that shocks or upsets other people
cards.example: She had the temerity to call me a liar.

cards.meaning: a short saying or poem that expresses an idea in an amusing way
cards.example: One of Oscar Wilde's most frequently quoted epigrams is "I can resist everything except temptation".

cards.meaning: a short clever saying that is intended to express a general truth
cards.example: We are all familiar with Tolstoy's apothegm: "Happy families are all alike; every unhappy family is unhappy in its own way."

cards.meaning: very careful to behave correctly or to give attention to details
cards.example: He was always punctilious in his manners.
